pages.text: I keep getting lost, and I have no idea where I'm going! I've tried making maps, but I keep shuffling them and they're all out of order and... ugh. It's time I make the most useful change I ever could; I need an organised Atlas that I can see in the corner of my eye at all times. I'll call it my $(6)$(l)minimap$().

pages.title: Making Your Atlas
pages.text: With a book, an adhesive such as slime or honey and a $(n)non-empty$() map, I easily bound together an Atlas. I've also saved a $(l)special slot$() for it, so it doesn't take up unnecessary space. The scale of my minimap will depend on the scale of the map I used to make it, of course, which I adjusted in the cartography table.

pages.title: Maintaining Your Atlas
pages.text: I've been exploring a lot, but haven't found a single soul yet. I've run out of pages in my Atlas. I'll have to make a lot more maps and add them to the Atlas using a cartography table.

pages.title: Editing Your Atlas
pages.text: Today I found a wandering trader! A sign of life! He said he had a map of the nearest village, so I used shears to rip a map of my own out of my Atlas to trade for it. I added the new map directly into my Atlas, and made a copy of the Atlas just in case.

pages.title: Keeping Track
pages.text: I've been having a lot of fun illustrating different things in my Atlas. I can only really draw out certain blocks, but it still helps keep track of where things are.$(br2)$(7)$(l)(Right-click a map-marker block with your Atlas to save a waypoint to your map.)$()

pages.title: Mapping Hell
pages.text: It seems my Atlas doesnâ€™t work as well in the Nether. I need a special type of map to be able to chart my surroundings, a slice map if you will, that charts the areas around me according to my elevation. I could also use this for caving in the overworld.
